subject: Re: [junit] Re: "No tests found" failures in Ant but not Eclipsee a
msgSnippet: Hi Heath, I misunderstood what you meant by generating failures . Somehow I was thinking compilation failures... Anyway, the problem is in the way you use the
messageBody:
Hi Heath,

I misunderstood what you meant by "generating failures". Somehow I was
thinking compilation failures... Anyway, the problem is in the way you
use the <batchtest/> element -- you're currently telling the JUnit
task to run all "*.java" files as JUnit tests, which obviously doesn't
work. Instead, you need to use patterns like "*Test.java" and
"Test*.java".

Lasse

--
Lasse Koskela
* Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *

On 6/7/07, hperryman <heath@...> wrote:
> The JUnit task can see all the code: all the tests are running fine,
> and getting the correct results. The only problem is that the helper
> classes that are also in the /test tree are generating failures about
> there not being any tests in the class.
>
> Sorry if I'm misunderstanding?
>
> Heath
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Lasse Koskela" <lasse.koskela@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hello Heath,
> >
> > Could you still list the contents of this classpath entry:
> >
> > <classpath refid="junit.classpath" />
> >
> > In order for Ant's JUnit task to see all the necessary code, that
> classpath
> > must point to both production and test source trees.
> >
> > Other than that, I cannot spot what else could be the culprit. Maybe
> someone
> > else has more fresh pair of eyes than myself?
> >
> > Lasse
> >
> > --
> > Lasse Koskela
> > * Author of "Test Driven" (Manning Publications, 2007) *
